description.plain:
Joey Bada$$ (born Jo-Vaughn Virginie Scott) is an American rapper, actor, and record producer hailing from Brooklyn, New York. Becoming known for his rugged style, an invigorating outcome of his Brooklyn neighborhood and surroundings, Joey Bada$$ has been a staple in the Hip-Hop industry for maintaining an authentic, unique and versatile sound. Whereas other rappers may take fewer risks with formulaic projects, Joey never shies away from keeping his music raw and original.

He is a co-founder of the collective Pro Era, with whom he has released two mixtapes and toured the globe multiple times.

Joey gained recognition after he released his debut mixtape, 1999, in June 2012 to critical acclaim and recognition, followed by Rejex in September, and Summer Knights on July 1, 2013.

His debut studio album, B4.DA.$$, released on 1/20/2015 through Pro Era Records / Cinematic Music Group, sold an impressive 56,000 units its opening week making it the #1 rap and #1 independent album in the country. The project henceforth received acclaim from his critics as well as his fans and is the catalyst that has placed Joey among Hip-Hop’s elite, as the album has sold 148,000+ copies worldwide to date.

After his debut album release in January, Joey has spent the better part of 2015 touring; playing overseas festivals; creating original music for soundtracks, such as Southpaw, as well as a national tour in the US, all while establishing the first annual Steez Day Festival in New York on July 7th, 2015.

Joey’s sophomore album, ALL-AMERIKKKAN BADA$$, was released on April 7, 2017, despite being leaked about a week earlier (which was due in part to an early physical press of the album). The project includes features from heavy-hitters such as ScHoolBoy Q, J. Cole and Styles P, as well as known collaborators Kirk Knight, Nyck Caution, Chronixx and Meechy Darko.

In an interview with XXL, Joey Badass stated that he was influenced by Nas, Tupac Shakur, Black Thought, MF DOOM, J Dilla, Andre 3000, Jay Z, and The Notorious B.I.G. He has received heavy comparison to late rapper Big L. He has also been compared to Nas during his Illmatic era.

songs.full_title: Survival Tactics by Joey Bada$$ (Ft. Capital STEEZ)
songs.title: Survival Tactics

description.plain:
Joey BADA$$ uses the instrumental for “Survival Tactics” by Styles of Beyond Prod. Vin Skully.

Joey borrows a lot of different flows from older artists (to compliment the old boom bap style he themed his work around) across the whole mixtape. Definitely spittin' on that Biggie flow when he’s like “When niggas start equippin, throw the clip in, etc etc.”

It has been alleged that Cinematic Music Group, the label under which Joey released the 1999 album, credited Joey with this song in an effort to focus attention on him even though it was a collaborative work with Capital STEEZ.

According to an article by the Fader Magazine:

“Survival Tactics” had initially been credited to Joey Bada$$ and Capital Steez—Steez had found the beat, and the song was his idea—but it had been rebranded as “Joey Bada$$ featuring Capital Steez” by the time the video made by Cinematic’s multimedia partner, Creative Control, was released

songs.title: Paper Trail$

description.plain:
Produced by the legendary DJ Premier, “Paper Trail$” revolves around how money has changed Joey in a negative way. He refers to Wu-Tang’s “C.R.E.A.M.” throughout the track to illustrate the point.

Joey described this song as the proper intro to B4.DA.$$. in an interview with Power 106 Los Angeles:

To me, ‘Paper Trail$’ was like the real intro to my album. Basically, I wanted to establish the where mind state I was at. The setting is in a place before the money, where I’d come to a point of realization where, you know, all of this stuff is going on in the world, and my generation is so focused on clothes and everything, but we’re still trapped. We really locked into the system… The whole essence of it is that really everything about money ruined everything around us. And this song I took ‘before the money’ to the extreme, I really thought about, like, a time before money even existed. So it was like cash ruin everything around us.

songs.title: Christ Conscious

description.plain:
Since mid 2014, Joey has performed the full verse during shows in North America and Europe. In addition, Joey previewed this song on Tim Westwood, along with “Big Dusty”, previous to its release.

Joey later teased fans with the cover art, and finally dropped it on September 30th.

songs.full_title: LAND OF THE FREE by Joey Bada$$
songs.title: LAND OF THE FREE

description.plain:
A political track that brings up mass incarceration, the bitter sweet contrast in American history for Afro-Americans, and Joey’s ambition to create change for the future.

The song was originally teased on January 16th for Martin Luther King day. ‘'Land of the Free’‘ was released on January 20th 2017—both Joey’s birthday and the day of Donald Trump’s inauguration—and is a single for Joey’s sophmore album AABA.

The artwork shows Joey in a ‘'Make Amerikkka Suck Again’‘ shirt with what seems to be an illustration of a Nazi eagle symbol, (Reichsadler). This can be interpreted as a criticism of Donald Trump’s 2016 campaign slogan ‘'Make America Great Again’'. Trump has been accused of ‘'dog whistling’' to the Alt-Right movement and other demographics who believe in white nationalism.

The backdrop is an illustration of inside the boats of the slave handle. This is the original image below:

songs.full_title: Hardknock by Joey Bada$$ (Ft. CJ Fly)
songs.title: Hardknock

description.plain:
Historical Context: Joey BADA$$:

“The only concept that was really behind it was how the people refer to the ‘90s as the golden age of hip-hop. So '99 being the last year of that age, it was basically like a "last hope” type of thing you feel me? It also coincides with the whole Y2K epidemic that was happening during that time so I felt it was perfect synchronization during that time only in 2012."

Rated #3 on the RapGenius Top 100 Rap Songs of the Year list.

The instrumental was produced by Lewis Parker, who sampled his own song, “Eyes Of Dream”.

songs.title: Waves

description.plain:
Joey borrowed this instrumental from the Freddie Joachim track also titled “Waves.”

This is the second song released from Joey BadA$$’s first solo project, “1999,” recorded when he was 17 years old. His performance of the song on The Tonight Show with Jimmy Fallon netted the Brooklyn native significant publicity. It was released as a follow-up to his debut video, “Survival Tactics.” The second offering has BadA$$ spitkicking on family, tofu dreams, and having the illest waves in his hood over mellow swelling Rhodes tones and a funky bassline. If you rode out to “Survival Tactics,” cool out, relax and reminisce to this one. The project is being released by SOW the brainchild of Cinematic Music Group and Creative Control.tv
The beat was later sampled by J. Cole in his song “False Prophets”.
Follow Joey @joeybadass_. No days off… child labor. – via

This is the first official song from Joey Badass for sale on iTunes along with his single “Enter the Void.” Purchase those singles here.

songs.title: DEVASTATED

description.plain:
Joey first previewed “Devastated” at Coachella on April 16, 2016.  On May 24, 2016 during fellow Pro Nyck Caution’s first headlining show at Baby’s All Right, Joey revealed the song would release the following Friday. On May 26, 2016 “Devastated” released on Pro Era’s YouTube channel.

In the song Joey discusses his pre-fame problems, and how he was “devastated” because he had not blown up.  He shares a resilient message about turning his struggles into a strength.

Joey took to Facebook on June 22, 2016 to share a very personal story from his childhood:

It was a really devastating moment in my life. You know, watching my mom battle a serious struggle, for me as a young child wasn’t anything I ever liked to see and I’m sure no child likes to see that. I used to come home from school and see eviction notices on our door.“ He admits he decided then that he would somehow pay his mom back for everything she did for him.

Joey also tagged the moving spiel with #IUsedToFeelSoDEVASTATED, inviting his fans to head over to his official website and share their own #devastated story or story of greatness.

On January 10th 2018, Devastated became Joey’s first song to reach RIAA Platinum status.

On this track, we see Joey explains himself and his struggles, from rising from the ghetto to  “taking care of business.” This cleverly named track, 95 Til Infinity, indicates not only that Joey will live forever (his legend/legacy), but his music will also.

description.plain:
The last song of the Joey Bada$$ album “1999” (2012). Includes the former members of Pro Era Capital Steez (deceased), T'nah Apex, and Dyemond Lewis. Based on the song “Suspect” by Nas off his sophomore album It Was Written.

In 2018, Joey Bada$$ released the mixtape onto streaming services, and the song was titled “Third Eye Sh*t.”

songs.title: Killuminati

description.plain:
This is the second straight song on 1999 that features Capital Steez.

After proceeding the fiery and extremely emotional track “Survival Tactics”, “Killuminati” does not by any means slow down the pace of the album, with Joey and STEEZ trading relentless flows while showing their love for wordplay and discussing their journey to put Pro Era on the map.

This song samples WhºK∆res by the producer Knxwledge.

songs.title: TEMPTATION

description.plain:
“TEMPTATION” finds Joey confronting racism and discrimination against African-Americans, a common theme explored throughout ALL-AMERIKKKAN BADA$$.

The intro and outro sample a recording of Zianna Oliphant, a nine-year-old girl from Charlotte, North Carolina. In the wake of the shooting death of Keith Lamont Scott by police, she made the speech to an audience at a council meeting.

Throughout the song, Joey asserts the same simple ideas as Zianna does in her speech – why does someone’s skin colour and ethnicity have bearing on their innate worth?

Joey first previewed “TEMPTATION” as well as the album’s 5th track, “DEVASTATED” at Coachella April 16, 2016.

The production used on “TEMPTATION” takes a melodic, catchy sample from “Oh Honey”, a song by the soul music group during the late 1970s, Delegation.

songs.title: World Domination

description.plain:
The seventh track on the 1999 mixtape uses the Datura Stramonium instrumental by MF Doom, which uses various samples. It’s worth noting that MF Doom used the melody in a skit marked as the sixth track on his album, MM.. Food.

Some may recognize this melody from the Fat Albert Halloween Special, and this chorus from Eminem’s Open Mic.

songs.title: Hazeus View

description.plain:
Track 6 on Joey Bada$$‘ highly anticipated debut album “B4.DA.$$”. Kirk Knight, fellow Pro Era MC and producer, comes through with a slow chill beat with a nice piano melody for this track.

On this song Joey contemplates his status as a rising star and his own spirituality, wondering if he’ll reach some greater understanding now that his music is starting to reach people and he’s becoming a sort of idol in his own right.

description.plain:
In a 2015 interview with Sway at South by Southwest, Joey spoke about the song’s meaning and how it was somewhat inspired by the Ryan Coogler film “Fruitvale Station”: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1DcZyEdSRBI

Joey premiered this song on The Tonight Show. He tackles social, political, and personal issues over a smooth instrumental.

In the last verse and chorus, Joey is seemingly speaking from his own perspective.

songs.full_title: ROCKABYE BABY by Joey Bada$$ (Ft. ScHoolboy Q)
songs.title: ROCKABYE BABY

description.plain:
“Rockabye Baby” is Joey Bada$$‘ and ScHoolboy Q’s reflection on their place in American society. Both rappers reflect on their drug dealing past and gang affiliations, and wage inequality for black people.

The track was released several hours before the official release on the 30th of March, to prevent it from getting leaked, and is the third single from Joey Bada$$‘ sophomore album, ALL-AMERIKKKAN BADA$$.

songs.full_title: Love Is Only a Feeling by Joey Bada$$
songs.title: Love Is Only a Feeling

description.plain:
“Love Is Only a Feeling” serves as Joey’s first solo release following his 2017 sophomore studio album, ALL-AMERIKKKAN BADA$$, and was released as a single alongside “500 Benz.”

This track’s beat and chorus samples HOMESHAKE’s “Love is Only a Feeling,” and is produced by frequent-collaborator and veteran producer Statik Selektah.

“Love Is Only a Feeling” has Joey raving about a girl, detailing how she is making him feel and also expressing his gratitude for being with her. – This strongly contrasts with the song’s title and chorus, stating that love is only a feeling.

songs.full_title: LEGENDARY by Joey Bada$$ (Ft. J. Cole)
songs.title: LEGENDARY

description.plain:
“LEGENDARY” is the first collaboration from Joey and J. Cole as a result of 2016’s False Prophets remix. In this song, the two introduce ideas such as spirituality, contentment and inner peace. Additionally, they question the way they, as “legends,” live their life and influence those around them.

Though this is the pair’s first collaboration, Joey stated in a Beats 1 interview that J. Cole was one of his favorite rappers when he was around 15-16 years old (another being Kendrick Lamar). According to the interview, Cole sent his verse in the day before 4 Your Eyez Only was released.

One thing the listener may notice immediately is how different Cole’s voice sounds as compared to his recent material from 4 Your Eyez Only.

songs.title_with_featured: On & On (Ft. Dyemond Lewis & Maverick Sabre)

description.plain:
A more sombre and introspective track for Joey, “On & On,” a piano-heavy ballad, was the fifth single to support his debut studio album B4.DA.$$.

UK artist Maverick Sabre delivers background vocals and the refrain, while fellow Pro Era member Dyemond Lewis delivers a featured verse.

At a show in Miami, Joey told the crowd that this song reminded him of “Snakes” and “Righteous Minds” off of his 1999 tape.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VzjYM7pp96Y&list=UUn9UxyrXsXdtP92nPNloKVg

songs.full_title: FOR MY PEOPLE by Joey Bada$$
songs.title: FOR MY PEOPLE

description.plain:
“FOR MY PEOPLE” details the social and political issues that people of color face day-to-day, such as police brutality, racism and other social ills. Joey also addresses his role as an artist and a voice in the fight for change against racism.

He continues to explore these themes throughout ALL-AMERIKKKAN BADA$$, with both the title and the content within a criticism of white America’s conduct.

songs.title: Daily Routine

description.plain:
For those interested, the OG sample is “The Highway Of My Life” by the Isley Brothers.

Part of the Songs from Scratch series which features rappers creating a song on the spot from scratch from a beat created from scratch. See where it all began:

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kQG7oNIGzn4

At first glance, 17-year-old Joey Bada$$ is like any of the cool kids at school: confident, and reluctant to reveal his secrets. The moment the beat drops, though, it becomes clear he doesn’t belong. Not with the cool crowd, maybe not with anyone. On a Thursday after school, Joey and his Pro-Era crew assembled at Brooklyn’s Dunham Studios — backpacks filled with laptops, laptops filled with loops – to create a new song, from scratch. Within minutes, the beat Chuck Strangers made only the night before sent Joey searching the insides of his eyelids for bars beyond his years. “Daily Routine,” the first in yours truly and adidas originals “Songs From Scratch” series, was written right there on the couch in the control room and is available for free download below.

description.plain:
Taking a break on the album’s theme of black empowerment and inequality, Joey, Meech, NYCk and Kirk express their discontent with the current lack of skill in the rap game.

They combat this by showcasing their own dynamic lyricism, something that “Beast Coast” artists are known for. The “Beast Coast” is a movement started in New York by the Progressive Era (Joey, Nyck, Kirk, etc.), the Flatbush Zombies (Meechy Darko and his group), and The Underachievers.

songs.title: BABYLON

description.plain:
This is the 10th song off ALL-AMERIKKKAN BADA$$. This song has a reggae vibe to it as Jamaican Reggae artiste, Chronixx is featured.

The name of the song, Babylon, originates from the ancient Mesopotamian city, mainly used in terms of religion and the Holy Bible.

Rastas, who refer to Selassie as the Lion of the tribe of Judea, take offense to Babylon and also make reference to oppressors as Babylon. Oppressors of the Rastafari religion include Police officers, who since the creation of Rastafari in the 1930s preyed on members because of its rapid growth and the fear of an uprising and a mass rebellion. Rastas can often be heard describing the government as Babylon system, police officers, Babylon bwoy, Dutty Babylon etc.

 Joey saw it fit to include a Chronixx feature as Chronixx himself is a follower of Rastafari. Black people also face oppression from law officials in the U.S. as many black people have been racially targeted.

songs.full_title: Don't Front by Joey Bada$$ (Ft. CJ Fly)
songs.title: Don’t Front

description.plain:
“Don’t Front” is the twelfth track from Joey Bada$$‘ mixtape, 1999. Joey sings about young love with a woman and his adventures with her, both good and bad. A hidden double meaning to the song can be revealed by examining not Joey’s love for a woman, but for marijuana.

This is the sample for the beat, produced by Statik Selektah.

songs.title: AMERIKKKAN IDOL

description.plain:
The final track on ALL-AMERIKKKAN BADA$$ shows Joey outright denouncing the American government, tackling negative stereotypes and calling out the government’s plan to exterminate the black people of America.

This title is a play on the show, American Idol. The show ran from June 11, 2002 – April 7, 2016. Coincidently, the release date of this album shares the same date that American Idol aired its last show.

songs.title: No. 99

description.plain:
“No. 99” is the third official single from Joey Bada$$‘ debut album B4.DA.$$ which releases on 1-20-15. Produced by Statik Selektah, it shares the same samples as “Scenario” by A Tribe Called Quest: The drum sample from “Little Miss Lover” by Jimi Hendrix and the bass line from “Oblighetto” by Brother Jack McDuff.

Here’s the official music video:
http://youtu.be/-LMnXxNdclg?t=1m44s

songs.title: Summer Knights

description.plain:
Joey’s professional debut, as the opening track for his debut project. “Summer Knights” introduces Joey and 1999 in more ways than one, touching on and developing the atmosphere, becoming more prevalent throughout the mixtape.

Summer Knights is also the name of his follow up projects Summer Knights, the full-length mixtape, and preceding EP

songs.full_title: Piece of Mind by Joey Bada$$
songs.title: Piece of Mind

description.plain:
This song is very similar to Nas’s “One Love” from his debut album Illmatic. Instead of writing a letter to his friend that is locked up, Joey is rapping a song dedicated to him.

Notice the wordplay “Piece of Mind” / “Peace of Mind”. Joey uses the line “Piece of Mind” in the song “95 Til Infinity”.

songs.full_title: Word Is Bond by Joey Bada$$
songs.title: Word Is Bond

description.plain:
First single off Joey’s album Summer Knights, due for release on June 12th.  The project was initially expected to be a mixtape or EP, but on May 28 (the date of this single’s release), the Brooklyn rapper tweeted Summer Knights would in fact be a full-length effort.

The track features a sample of the lyrics spoken by Tupac on the Big L song Deadly Combination, but the sample in the track is not Pac. The instrumental also contains a predominant sample of “Amour” by Kleeer

songs.title: Black Beetles

description.plain:
“Black Beetles” is the 13th track on B4.DA.$$. It is arguably the darkest song on the album and has Joey rapping about his self-esteem and how his experience being a rap star isn’t as great as he thought it would be.

The instrumental for “Black Beetles” was first previewed and introduced in the first B4.DA.$$ trailer.

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7J9VcUKwSRw

Watch the video below to see Joey and Sway talk about the lyrics:

http://youtu.be/LP5D6Jlc_p8?t=10m19s

songs.title: O.C.B.

description.plain:
These are Joey’s “Only Child Blues.”

“O.C.B.” sees Joey reminiscing on his upbringing without birth-siblings and on his relationship with his parents. Conversations with his mother are sampled in the chorus and outro as well, further cementing the theme.

OCB, established  1918, Finistere, France, is also a popular brand of rolling papers throughout the world—as well as in Saint Lucia, where Joey’s mother is from.

songs.full_title: GOOD MORNING AMERIKKKA by Joey Bada$$
songs.title: GOOD MORNING AMERIKKKA

description.plain:
The opening track, “Good Morning AmeriKKKa” delves into the elements of this album: racism, freedom, politics, and happiness.

The song title is an innocent greeting to Joey’s views on “Amerikkka,” as noted by the spelling with “KKK” instead of the usual “C”. KKK is an abbreviation for Klu Klux Klan, a group that advocates white supremacy, white nationalism, anti-immigration and antisemitism. The 3 K’s is also likely a nod to Ice Cube’s debut solo album AmeriKKKa’s Most Wanted, and Capital STEEZ’s debut mixtape AmeriKKKan Koruption

songs.full_title: Y U DON'T LOVE ME? (MISS AMERIKKKA) by Joey Bada$$
songs.title: Y U DON’T LOVE ME? (MISS AMERIKKKA)
songs.title_with_featured: Y U DON'T LOVE ME? (MISS AMERIKKKA)

description.plain:
On this track, Joey confronts his identity and the identity of African-Americans within the context of America as a whole.

This is Joey’s version of an unrequited love song about America. He treats America as a female (Miss Amerikkka) who just doesn’t treat him right.

The “Miss Amerikkka” name stems from the personification of a country’s attitude towards one race and also from the lack of racial diversity in Miss America pageants.
